Chief Complaint: Respiratory distress and hypotension
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   73 y.o. man CRF, HD, anuric, afib on coumadin at home, CAD, CABG, SDH.
   Fall [**8-12**] - acute on chronic SDH on left.  Seizures also complicating
   course.  Loaded with dilantin on neurology following recurrent
   seizure.  Last evening had acute respiratory distress with desturations
   to low 90's on 3L NC.  SBP decreased to 70's - responsive to IV NS
   fluid challenge.  Temp 101.9 prior to transfer.  Empirically started on
   vanco/gentamycin with dialysis dosing for ?line infection.  No growth
   on cultures to date.

   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**]):  Given purulent
   secretions, fever a likely component is superimposed tracheobronchitis,
   possible PNA.  Will add cefipime to antibiotics.  Follow vanco level,
   redose as indicated.  MDIs inline with ventilator given history of
   asthma, doesn't seem tight on exam now.  No steroids.  Volume status
   will also be important, minimize fluids if possible.
 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA):  Probable PNA as
   above.  Line infection seems less likely given multiple negative
   cultures including prior to starting antibiotics.  Repeat clutures and
   line tip culture pending.  Will follow up on these.
 HYPOTENSION:  Possible sepsis on levophed, may be component of
   intravascular depletion albeit hesitant to be aggressive with fluids.
   Try to wean.  If unable to wean will try gentle fluid challenge.
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM):  SDH as below.  Now sedated on
   propofol, also active infection will exacerbate.
 ACUTE ON CHRONIC SDH:  Stable neurological exam.  Repeat scan [**8-17**]
   showed no change.
 RENAL FAILURE, END STAGE (END STAGE RENAL DISEASE, ESRD):  Last
   dialyzed yesterday.  Truncated for unclear reasons albeit they were
   apparently having trouble with flow through left subclavian dialysis
   catheter so this was also taken out.  Tip sent for culture.
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II:  Sugars adequately controlled on
   RISS in setting of infection.
 SEIZURE, WITHOUT STATUS EPILEPTICUS:  Stable on dilantin.  Check
   levels.
 ASSYMETRIC UPPER EXTREMITY EDEMA:  Greater on side of PICC line.
   Ultrasound to evaluate for thrombosis.  [**Month (only) 11**] be another etiology of
   fever albeit higher than would be expected unlesss infected.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of chronic renal failure, hypertension, atrial fibrillation on coumadin, coronary artery disease, and previous stroke. He presented with acute respiratory distress, hypotension, and fever. The patient had a fall resulting in an acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) and experienced seizures, for which he was loaded with dilantin.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors. He developed respiratory failure, likely secondary to superimposed tracheobronchitis or pneumonia (PNA), for which cefipime was added to his antibiotic regimen. The patient also had an unknown origin fever, initially suspected to be a line infection but now believed to be PNA. Cultures have been repeated and the line tip culture is pending.

The patient's hypotension is attributed to possible sepsis and intravascular depletion. He is currently on levophed and being managed carefully with fluid challenges.

The patient's mental status is altered due to the SDH and active infection. He is sedated on propofol and his condition will likely worsen.

Renal failure, end-stage (ESRD), is present, and the patient's most recent dialysis session was truncated. The dialysis catheter was also removed and sent for culture.

Diabetes mellitus type II is well-controlled in the setting of infection.

The patient experienced a seizure,

   -- oon versed/fentanyl for sedation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male admitted with left subdural hematoma causing seizure, on hemodialysis without residual urine output, and possible line infection on gentamicin and vancomycin. He is being transferred for respiratory distress, hypotension, and hypoxia. The patient is now intubated, oxygenating well, likely has pneumonia per chest X-ray and fevers. He continues to require levophed. The patient also has a history of atrial fibrillation, not on coumadin due to recent subdural hematoma.

24-Hour Events:
- Fever of 102.4 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Patient covered with vancomycin and cefepime, gentamicin discontinued.
- Large volumes of bilious return from NG tube (nasogastric tube), patient passing flatus and has active bowel sounds (no ileus).

Allergies:
- Hydromorphone
- Metoclopramide

Last dose of antibiotics:
- Cefepime - [**2191-8-21**] 02:06 PM

Infusions:
- Fentanyl - 35 mcg/hour
- Midazolam (Versed) - 1 mg/hour
- Norepinephrine - 0.03 mcg/Kg/min

Other ICU medications:
- Pantoprazole (Protonix) - [**2191-8-21**] 08

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male admitted with left subdural hematoma (SDH) due to a seizure, on hemodialysis (HD) without residual urine output, and possible line infection on gentamicin/vancomycin. He was transferred for respiratory distress, hypotension, and hypoxia. The patient is now intubated, oxygenating well, and likely has pneumonia per chest X-ray and fevers. He continues to require levophed support. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, not on coumadin due to recent SDH. 

24-hour events:
- Fever of 102.4 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Patient covered with vancomycin and cefepime, gentamicin discontinued.
- Large volumes of bilious return from nasogastric tube (NGT), patient passing flatus and has active bowel sounds (no ileus).
- Allergies to hydromorphone and metoclopramide.
- Last dose of antibiotics was cefepime on [**2191-8-21**] at 02:06 PM.
- Infusions of fentanyl, midazolam, and norepinephrine.
- Other ICU medications include pantoprazole, midazolam, fentanyl, and fosphenytoin.
- Review of systems unchanged from admission except as noted below.
- Vital signs: Tmax of 39.1 degrees Celsius, Tcurrent of 37.3 degrees Celsius, HR of 83 bpm, BP of 121/42 mmHg, RR of 18 breaths per minute, SpO2 of 94%.
- Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm.
- Fluid balance: Total in 985 mL, total out 1730 mL, negative balance -745 mL.
- Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt of 0-500 mL, set RR of 0, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, RSBI of 79, PIP of 0 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 22 cmH2O, compliance of 0 cmH2O/mL, SpO2 of 94%.
- ABG results: pH of 7.31, PaCO2 of 44 mmHg, PaO2 of 185 mmHg, HCO3 of 74 mEq/L, BE of -4 mEq/L, Ve of 8.4 L/min, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 185.
- Physical examination: Cardiovascular system within normal limits, reduced left-sided breath sounds, abdomen benign and active bowel sounds, symmetrical peripheral edema.
- Neurologic examination: Not assessed due to intubation.
- Labs: WBC of 14.0 K/uL, Hct of 37

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male admitted with left subdural hematoma causing seizure, on hemodialysis without residual urine output, and possible line infection on gentamicin and vancomycin. The patient is being transferred for respiratory distress, hypotension, and hypoxia. 

24-hour events include the placement of a temporary dialysis line, positive sputum cultures for GNR and G+ Cocci in pairs, and initiation of dialysis catheter with sideport. The patient has allergies to hydromorphone and metoclopramide, and has received antibiotics including cefepime and vancomycin. 

Vital signs show tachycardia, hypertension, and mild hypoxia. Fluid balance indicates a positive fluid intake of 1,028 mL and output of 450 mL. Respiratory support is provided through an endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 of 40%, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. 

Physical examination reveals cardiovascular stability, clear lung sounds, soft and distended abdomen, trace edema, and decreased peripheral pulses. Neurologic examination is not assessable due to sedation and intubation. 

Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lipase levels. Imaging and microbiology results are pending. 

Assessment and plan include alterations in nutrition, respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, renal failure, hypertension, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure without status epilepticus. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include respiratory distress, volume overload, possible aspiration event, pulmonary embolism, sepsis, hypotension, line infection, high bilious output via NG tube, inflammatory process in the abdomen, inflammatory bowel disease, end-stage renal disease, atrial fibrillation, seizure activity, subdural hematoma, glaucoma, cataracts, asthma exacerbation, diabetes management, and access issues.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was initially admitted for an acute on chronic subdural hematoma caused by a fall. The patient suffered a seizure and was transferred to the MICU for respiratory distress, hypoxia, fever, and hypotension. The patient's hemodialysis (HD) line was removed due to concern for bacteremia, and sputum cultures showed growth of Gram-negative rods (GNR) and Gram-positive cocci (GPC).

The patient has been receiving antibiotics, specifically vancomycin and cefepime, for suspected pneumonia. The patient's respiratory status has been managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV). The patient's mental status is altered, and no sedation is being used.

The patient has a high output of bilious nasogastric (NG) aspirate, suggesting a possible inflammatory process or obstruction. The patient's fluid balance is negative due to the NG output. The patient's dialysis catheter was replaced today, and renal consultation was obtained for further management of ESRD.

The patient is currently in sinus rhythm, and anticoagulation is being held for an acute on chronic subdural hematoma. The patient's right upper extremity is swollen, and a duplex ultrasound is planned to evaluate for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's seizure activity is controlled with

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and chronic left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH). He was admitted to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, hypertension, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Distress: The patient has acute respiratory failure, likely secondary to pneumonia (PNA) indicated by sputum gram stain significant for gram-negative rods (GNR) and gram-positive cocci (GPC). Intubation was challenging due to mental status changes, fluid overload, and underlying infection. The patient is currently on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and will continue with daily weaning attempts once hemodialysis (HD) is re-initiated.
2. Volume Overload: The patient has fluid overload, which was addressed by replacing the temporary dialysis catheter with another temporary catheter via interventional radiology (IR). Pressures have been stable, and the patient underwent HD yesterday.
3. Pneumonia: The patient is being treated with vancomycin (day 9) and cefepime (9) for GP and GN coverage. Antibiotic therapy will be adjusted based on culture and sensitivity results.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old individual who was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) due to left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure. The patient is also experiencing respiratory distress, hypotension, fever, and altered mental status.

The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, benign, type II diabetes mellitus (DM), and seizure without status epilepticus. The patient's current conditions include acute respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, hypoglycemia, pneumonia, and high-output NG.

The assessment and plan include addressing the following issues:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on pressure support ventilation (PSV) with plans for daily weaning attempts once hemodialysis (HD) is re-initiated.
2. Volume overload: The temporary dialysis catheter has been replaced, and pressures have been stable. The patient underwent HD yesterday.
3. Pneumonia: The patient is receiving vancomycin and cefepime for gram-positive and gram-negative coverage. Antibiotic therapy will be adjusted based on culture and sensitivity results.
4. Mental status: No sedation will be continued for further evaluation of mental status.
5. Hypotension/fevers: The patient's blood pressure has improved since the placement of an axillary arterial line. Low-grade fever was recorded overnight.
6. High bilious

The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) with seizures. The patient has been on hemodialysis (HD) due to ESRD and was transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin (FUO), altered mental status, hypertension, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and a seizure episode. The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to volume overload, underlying infection, and pneumonia (PNA) supported by sputum gram stain showing significant gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci.

The patient's hypotension and fever indicate a potential infection, and the patient has completed a course of vancomycin. The patient's hypotension is also related to septic shock, and he has been restarted on levophed.

The patient has a high bilious output without evidence of obstruction or ileus. This may represent an inflammatory process or another cause unrelated to gallbladder or pancreas involvement.

The patient's end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requires ongoing hemodialysis (HD) management.

The patient's right upper extremity swelling is due to a non-occlusive clot.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for acute respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypotension. The patient had left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing a seizure, and he was transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis.

The patient's current condition includes fever with unknown origin, altered mental status, respiratory failure, hypertension, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure. He is on mechanical ventilation in the prone position with non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV). His vital signs are as follows: temperature of 102.3°F, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure of 103/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN), elevated creatinine, low albumin, elevated potassium, and elevated glucose levels. Imaging shows increased hilar density on chest X-ray without effusions.

Plan:

1. Respiratory Distress: Continue pressure support ventilation (PSV) with daily weaning attempts once hemodialysis (HD) is re-initiated.
2. Volume Overload: Continue HD.
3. Pneumonia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure, and later transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.
- The patient has multiple medical conditions including respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS), fever of unknown origin (FUO), altered mental status (not delirium), end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, benign, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus (DM) type II, and seizure without status epilepticus.
- The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 102.3°F, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 70s systolic to 103/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 96%, and sinus tachycardia heart rhythm.
- The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation support with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 of 40%, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, and PS of 10 cmH2O.
- The patient's physical examination reveals reduced breath sounds at the bases, distended abdomen without tenderness, no extremity edema, and sacral edema.
- The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, elevated creatinine, potassium, and liver enzymes.

   Patient with initial history notable for sub-dural hematoma complicated
   by seizures subsequently who now has persistent renal failure and
   recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis.  Of concern is that patient
   has had evidence of significant fever in the setting of a mild rise in
   WBC count.  This is without localizing laboratory findings.
   1)Sepsis-
   -Levophed
   -Vanco/Cefepime
   -Will resend cultures from blood, sputum and urine
   -Will continue Vanco at this time
   -Follow cultures
   -Will go to broad spectrum antibiotics in the setting of increased
   pressor requirements
   -Will have to expand to coverage to focus on VAP with Vanco/Meropenem
   2)Respiratory Failure-
   -Atrovent/Albuterol
   -Continue with PSV support
   -Maintain O2
   3)Renal Failure-
   -Will move to CVVH in the setting of hypotension if unable to tolerate
   HD over next 24 hours
   4)Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status-He has persistent deficit as
   described above
   -Will repeat head CT to evaluate stability of bleed or new obvious
   insult
   -Will follow neuro exam
   -Will continue hold of sedation and follow exam
   -Without trend to improvement will have to raise concern for persistent
   neurologic deficit

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a sub-dural hematoma, respiratory failure, and renal failure. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been febrile since admission. The patient has a history of seizures and is on antiepileptic medication. His vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension, with a fever of 102.3 F. He has right lower extremity edema and absent peripheral pulses in both lower extremities. Neurologically, he is unresponsive but moves his lower extremities to stimulation. Lab results indicate elevated WBC count, elevated creatinine, and decreased albumin levels. Blood cultures are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's recurrent fever and mild rise in WBC count suggest a possible infection, which could progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation and respiratory failure, there is a risk of developing VAP. This would require broad-spectrum antibiotics and possibly changing ventilator settings.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate ongoing renal dysfunction. This may require further dialysis or renal replacement therapy.
4. Neurological deficits: The patient's persistent altered mental status and lack of reliable withdrawal response indicate potential ongoing neurological damage. Repeat head CT scans will be necessary to assess the stability of the sub-dural hemat

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male who is HD-dependent and admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure. The patient was transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure not associated with ARDS. The etiology includes volume overload due to anuric renal failure and likely pneumonia supported by sputum gram stain significant for GNR and GPC. Barriers to intubation include mental status, fluid overload, and underlying infection.

2. Hypotension/Fever: The patient spiked temperatures overnight and was pan-cultured. The patient has known MRSA pneumonia and completed a course of vancomycin today. Hypotension was also noted, and the patient was restarted on levophed. Vancomycin and cefepime will continue for concern of pneumosepsis pending cultures and sensitivities.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, but it is not delirium. Correction of electrolyte disturbances and treatment of infection are ongoing.

4. Renal Failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). HD or continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) will be initiated tomorrow.

5. High Bilious

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypotension. He has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, pneumonia, and sepsis.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 101.4°F (38.6°C), heart rate of 96 bpm, blood pressure of 139/56 mmHg (93/38 mmHg), respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, increased creatinine levels, hyperglycemia, and electrolyte imbalances. The patient also has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure disorder.

The patient's imaging studies reveal right lower lobe opacity on chest X-ray, which is consistent with pulmonary edema. The microbiology report indicates the presence of gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters.

The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, and hypertension. The patient is currently being treated for pneumonia with vancomycin, cefepime, gentamicin, and meropenem. The patient is also receiving continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to renal failure.

The patient's current plan includes continuing mechanical ventilation, hemodialysis, and antibiotic therapy. The patient's mental status is being evaluated, and electrolyte disturbances are being corrected. The patient's fever and hypotension are being closely monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI), and worsening renal function. Close monitoring and appropriate interventions are necessary to prevent these complications.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of subdural hematoma, persistent renal failure, and recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis. He is currently in the ICU and has several medical complications.

1) Sepsis: The patient is being treated with vancomycin and gentamicin antibiotics. His fever curve should be monitored.
2) Respiratory Failure: The patient is on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and will initiate continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) to improve fluid status and mental status, bringing us closer to extubation.
3) Renal Failure: CVVH will be initiated today for renal failure management.
4) Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: Sedation will be held to assess any changes in mental status.
5) Seizure Disorder: The patient is on Neurontin and Dilantin for seizure management.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38°C (101.4°F), heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure of 105/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, lactic acid, and liver enzymes. His glucose level is also elevated.

1. Respiratory failure due to underlying infection and fluid overload.
2. Volume overload leading to pulmonary edema.

5. Hypotension requiring vasopressor support.
6. Fever in the setting of hypotension, indicating possible infection.
7. Mental status changes due to electrolyte imbalances, infection, or SDH.
8. ESRD requiring dialysis.
9. AF with no anticoagulation due to SDH.
10. Non-occlusive clot in the right upper extremity.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted for a seizure caused by a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).
- He has been in the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.
- The patient has been experiencing fever, altered mental status, respiratory failure, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and a seizure.
- He was started on vancomycin and meropenem due to suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) but no growth was found.
- The patient's condition has been complicated by several issues, including hypotension, fever, white count, volume overload, underlying infection, respiratory distress, pneumonia, and mental status changes.
- His nutrition has been a concern, but he is now tolerating tube feeds (TF) with clear residuals.
- The patient's renal function is impaired, and CVVH filter clotted.
- He is currently on CVVH, and a trial of hemodialysis (HD) was attempted today.
- The patient has a history of glaucoma, cataracts, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure.
- His current medications include norepinephrine, insulin, pantoprazole, and various ICU medications.
- The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 101.1°F, heart rate of 93

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), admitted to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient has several medical complications and ongoing issues:

1. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has had a persistent fever overnight, which is concerning for an underlying infection. The patient has been pan cultured and is currently on antibiotics for MRSA and GNR coverage.

2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, requiring the use of levophed to maintain adequate blood pressure. This may indicate septic shock or another cause of distributive shock.

3. Renal Failure: The patient has a history of ESRD and is currently undergoing continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVH). However, the CVVH filter has clotted, and there are plans for a trial of intermittent hemodialysis (HD) today.

4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) due to acute respiratory failure. There is concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) given the sputum gram stain showing GNR and GPC. The patient is being treated empirically for both MRSA and GNR.

5. Mental Status Changes: The patient has altered mental status, which may be related to infection, electrolyte imbalances

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old man with a chief complaint of renal failure, respiratory failure, and subdural hematoma. The patient's medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, seizures, and end-stage renal disease. 

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been receiving norepinephrine infusion for hemodynamic support. He is also receiving insulin to maintain glycemic control. 

The patient has been experiencing recurrent fever, which is concerning for an ongoing infection. The patient's mental status has improved after receiving antibiotics, but he remains sedated due to encephalopathy. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine levels indicating renal dysfunction, and elevated blood glucose levels. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.1°F, blood pressure ranging from 125/57 mmHg to 151/59 mmHg, heart rate between 98-106 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. 

The patient's physical examination reveals crackles in the lungs, symmetrical chest expansion, and normal heart sounds. The neurologic examination shows that the patient is attentive and follows simple commands but has not been fully assessed due to sedation. 

The patient has several potential medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizures. He has been in the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient continues to have fevers, pan cultured on 8/28. Levophed was restarted yesterday and has required levophed off and on, now on. The concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) was considered due to sputum gram stain with gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters. However, no growth was observed. The patient is on vancomycin and meropenem, with meropenem being empiric for gram-negative rods.

The patient's respiratory distress is attributed to volume overload, as indicated by the resuscitation with anuric renal failure. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (GNR) and gram-positive cocci (GPC) were found in the sputum gram stain. Barriers to extubation include mental status, fluid overload, and underlying infection. 

The patient's mental status is being evaluated further, and electrolyte disturbances are being corrected. Infection treatment is ongoing. The patient has a non-occlusive clot in the mid axillary vein, but the PICC line will not be pulled out. 

The patient's end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requires ongoing hemodialysis (HD) treatment. The patient is in normal sinus rhythm (NSR

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizures. He has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). The patient was transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. He has been experiencing fevers, pan cultured on 8-28, and required levophed off and on for hypotension. He is currently on vancomycin and meropenem.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient continues to have hypotension despite being on levophed. This may indicate ongoing sepsis or another underlying cause such as heart failure or significant blood loss.

2. Fevers: The patient has been experiencing fevers, which could be due to an ongoing infection. The source of infection is still pending, but there is a suspicion of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) given the sputum gram stain showing gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters.

3. Respiratory Distress: The patient has respiratory failure and is currently on pressure support ventilation (PSV). Barriers to extubation include mental status, fluid overload, and underlying infection. The patient needs to be weaned off the ventilator once HD is re-initiated.

4. Volume Overload: The patient has fluid overload, which is contributing to the respiratory distress

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of subdural hematoma, respiratory failure, and renal failure. He is currently experiencing fever, altered mental status, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure disorder. The patient's medical team has identified several potential complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has persistent fever and elevated white blood cell count, indicating an ongoing infection. He is being treated with vancomycin and meropenem, but his temperature is still spiking. A right upper quadrant ultrasound will be performed, and the PICC line will be removed.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and will aim for one more hemodialysis session before attempting extubation.

3. Renal Failure: The patient requires further hemodialysis due to renal failure.

4. Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is improving, but he still has a subdural hematoma. 

5. Seizure Disorder: The patient has a seizure disorder and is currently being treated with phenytoin and dilantin.

6. PICC Line Clot: The preliminary read of the right upper extremity ultrasound shows that the PICC line is stable, and it will be planned to pull the PICC line.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the MICU with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure, hypoxia, and hypotension. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus type II, and hypertension.

The patient's current medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient continues to have fevers despite being on antibiotics.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, which is not delirium. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.

3. Respiratory Failure, Acute: The patient has acute respiratory failure, not ARDS. He requires mechanical ventilation support.

4. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had episodes of hypoglycemia.

5. Right Upper Extremity Swelling: The patient has swelling in the right upper extremity, and an ultrasound shows a non-occlusive clot. The PICC line has been pulled due to fevers.

6. ESRD: The patient has end-stage renal disease and requires regular hemodialysis.

7. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is in normal sinus rhythm, but anticoagulation has been held due to the underlying SDH.

8. High Bilious Output: The patient initially had a high bilious output, but this has resolved.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old man with multiple medical complications. The chief complaints mentioned are respiratory failure, subdural hematoma, and septic shock. The patient has a history of subdural hematoma complicated by seizures, persistent renal failure, and recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis.

The patient is currently receiving several treatments and interventions, including hemodialysis (HD), mechanical ventilation, norepinephrine infusion, antibiotics (Vancomycin and Meropenem), pantoprazole, fosphenytoin, and others as per ICU resident notes.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.1 C (100.5 F), blood pressure ranging from 105/44 mmHg to 147/67 mmHg, heart rate between 81-105 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 95%. The patient's weight is 89.4 kg, and height is 70 inches.

The patient's lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC), creatinine (Cr), and lactate levels. Other lab values are within normal limits or show variations.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, normocephalic head, symmetric chest expansion, breath sounds with crackles, soft and non-tender abdomen, trace lower extremity edema, warm skin, and attentive neurologic status with no follow-through commands.

- The patient attempted extubation but failed and was reintubated.
- The patient may require a tracheostomy and long-term ventilation.
- The patient completed a 10-day course of MRSA pneumonia treatment and is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient's mental status has improved, and the recent CT scan showed no worsening of SDH.
- The patient's electrolyte disturbances need correction, and infections need to be treated.
- The patient had a seizure, but no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity is observed.

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, and acute on chronic subdural hematoma. He was admitted with fever, hypoxia, and hypotension. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing multiple complications including fever of unknown origin, altered mental status, hypoglycemia, seizure, pneumonia, scrotal and buttock lesions, right upper extremity swelling, end-stage renal disease, atrial fibrillation, high bilious output, subdural hematoma, renal cyst, glaucoma, cataracts, diabetes mellitus, and poor wound healing.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient may require a tracheostomy and long-term ventilation due to his inability to ventilate on his own.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has completed a 10-day course of MRSA pneumonia treatment. However, there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) given his prolonged intubation.
3. Renal failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease and requires ongoing hemodialysis. There is a risk of further deterioration in renal function.
4. Seizure: The patient had a seizure episode, and there is a risk of recurrent seizures due to underlying neurologic conditions.

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of subdural hematoma, persistent renal failure, and recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis. He has been critically ill and requires ongoing medical interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock: The patient is experiencing low-grade fevers and ongoing pressor requirements, indicating possible septic shock. There is also purulent discharge from his HD line, which could be a source of infection. The access for lines is an issue, with the VIP port being the only central access for pressors. Other potential line insertion sites are suboptimal.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient failed extubation yesterday and his mental status is slow to clear. This suggests the possibility of respiratory failure. Tracheostomy may be needed to secure the airway.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has persistent renal failure and is on hemodialysis.
4. Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: The patient has a subdural hematoma and altered mental status. There is progressive improvement in his condition, but he may still require close monitoring and neurological assessment.
5. Seizure Disorder: The patient has had seizures, and antiepileptic medications (Neurontin and Dilantin) have been initiated.
6. PICC line clot: The patient had a PICC line clot, which has been removed.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing a seizure. He is dependent on hemodialysis and has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), and glaucoma/cataracts. The patient presented with hypotension, hypoxia, and fever, leading to concern for sepsis. He was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further management.

24-hour events include bolusing IV phenytoin 300mg and checking free dilantin in the morning, starting midodrine, and performing a magnetic resonance venography (MRV) that revealed narrowing of right subclavian and brachiocephalic veins, as well as narrowing of left subclavian and internal jugular veins. The patient also has an enlarged mediastinal lymph node, unchanged from prior imaging.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 131/48 mmHg (79/40 mmHg), respiratory rate of 77 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is currently receiving norepinephrine at 0.05 mcg/kg/min and has various infusions and medications running.

Lab results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 23400

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure, and subsequently transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) due to concerns of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). He also has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), glaucoma, cataracts, and scrotal and buttock lesions that are likely dependent skin ulcers. The patient's current condition includes respiratory distress, hypotension, fever, white blood cell count elevation, and mental status changes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient may require tracheostomy and long-term ventilation due to failed extubation attempts and ongoing respiratory distress.
2. Volume overload: The patient may continue with hemodialysis to manage fluid overload.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has been treated for MRSA pneumonia and may develop ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
4. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient's central line is infected, which requires appropriate treatment and consideration for line replacement.
5. Seizure: The patient had a seizure, and ongoing seizure activity should be monitored. Further evaluation of mental status and management of seizure risk should be considered.
6. Skin

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with a complex medical history including subdural hematoma, persistent renal failure, recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis, septic shock, respiratory failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure disorder. 

The patient is currently in the ICU with the following ongoing issues:
1) Septic shock - The patient has low-grade fevers and requires ongoing pressor support. Vancomycin has been continued, and midodrine has been added to try to wean off the pressors after hemodialysis (HD).
2) Respiratory Failure - The patient's mental status has improved today, and it is planned to attempt extubation over the weekend if the mental status continues to improve. However, tracheostomy remains a possibility based on the goals of care.
3) Renal Failure - HD is planned for today.
4) Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status - The patient's mental status has improved today.
5) Seizure Disorder - The patient is on Neurontin and Dilantin.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 38.2°C (100.8°F)
- Heart rate: 86 bpm
- Blood pressure: 103/39 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 100% on endotracheal tube with FiO

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing seizures. He has been in the MICU for concerns of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient has been experiencing fevers, likely due to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and gross pus from his right hemodialysis line, which could be a potential source of infection. He has been started on vancomycin due to the positive culture for MRSA and requires continued pressure support with levophed. The patient attempted extubation two days ago but failed and was reintubated. There are plans to switch to pressure support today and consider tracheostomy placement for long-term ventilation. The patient also has scrotal and buttock lesions, most likely dependent skin ulcers, for which herpes DFA will be done and wound care will continue. The patient's seizure activity is being monitored, and phenytoin has been administered. The patient may undergo hemodialysis today. His anticoagulation is being held, and he will follow neurology recommendations for subdural hematoma. He has controlled diabetes and glaucoma/cataracts, and his nutritional intake is being closely monitored.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 73-year-old man admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing seizures. He was transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient continues to have fevers, indicating possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), with sputum positive for minimal Staphylococcus aureus. There is also gross pus from the right hemodialysis (HD) line, which could be a source of infection. The patient has been on vancomycin, which was pan-culture negative on day 8. 

The patient requires continued pressure support with levophed due to respiratory distress, likely secondary to pneumonia or pulmonary edema. A trial of extubation was attempted two days ago but failed, and the patient is now reintubated. There is consideration for tracheostomy placement for long-term ventilation. 

The patient has dependent skin ulcers on the scrotal and buttock area, which are most likely due to pressure from being bedridden. A herpes DFA test is planned to rule out herpes infection. 

The patient's EEG is negative for ongoing seizure activity, so there is no gross evidence of a seizure. Phenytoin has been administered, and the patient's dilantin level will be followed up in the morning. 

The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and may undergo hemodialysis today. Anticoagulation is being held, and neurology recommendations will be followed. 

The patient has glaucoma and cataracts, for which he continues to use home eye drops. His diabetes is well-controlled with insulin. 

Regarding access, the patient has an axillary arterial line, a temporary line for HD (which is infected), and is attempting to wean off pressors to pull the HD line. 

Nutritionally, the patient is tolerating tube feeding (TF). 

The patient's prophylactic measures include pneumoboots, PPI, and bowel regimen. 

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to remain in the ICU while intubated. The family has been updated on the patient's condition. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's continued fevers and positive sputum culture for MRSA suggest the possibility of VAP. It is crucial to continue appropriate antibiotic therapy and maintain proper airway management.

2. Pressure ulcers: The presence of dependent skin ulcers on the scrotal and buttock area indicates the need for regular repositioning and wound care to prevent further development or worsening of these pressure ulcers.

3. Sepsis: The patient's initial presentation of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension, along with the current fevers and positive sputum culture, raises concerns for ongoing sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs

Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus type II, and hypertension. He was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.
- The patient had a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) that caused a seizure, leading to his transfer to the MICU.
- On day 8, the patient developed fever and was found to have pneumonia with sputum positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Vancomycin was initiated and continued for a 10-day course.
- The patient also has respiratory distress, likely secondary to pneumonia or pulmonary edema. He attempted a trial of extubation but failed and was reintubated. A switch to pressure support ventilation is being considered, along with the possibility of tracheostomy placement for long-term ventilation.
- The patient has scrotal and buttock lesions, which are most likely dependent skin ulcers. Herpes DFA is pending, and wound care will continue.
- There is no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity, and an EEG is negative. Neurology recommendations include continuing IV phenytoin and following up on the phenytoin level.
- The patient has ESRD and will undergo hemodialysis (HD) on Monday.
- Anticoagulation is

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), who was admitted to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient has several medical conditions, including altered mental status, respiratory failure, hypoglycemia, diabetes mellitus type II, and seizure disorder.

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure ranging from 139/53 to 171/64 mmHg, heart rate between 74 and 99 bpm, respiratory rate of 15-32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is sedated and intubated, with a ventilator set in CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, normal platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, and normal glucose levels. Imaging shows low lung volumes without opacities, and microbiology tests reveal sputum positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

The patient's plan of care includes continuing midodrine and reducing levophed as tolerated, attempting to add florinef for further blood pressure support, keeping mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65, and continuing vancomycin given the recent positive culture for MRSA to complete a 10-day course

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing seizure. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus type II, and glaucoma/cataracts. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has been febrile, with the source of infection possibly being a line infection, as surveillance cultures have been drawn. The patient's renal function is impaired, and he is scheduled for hemodialysis on Monday. He also has scrotal and buttock lesions, which are likely dependent skin ulcers, and an EEG has been performed to assess for ongoing seizure activity. The patient's nutritional status is being monitored, and his blood sugars are well-controlled on SSI and lantus 40 daily.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and potential line infection indicate a high risk for sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory parameters is necessary to identify early signs of septic shock.

2. Respiratory Distress: The patient's inability to maintain secretions and failure of attempted trial of extubation suggest a high risk for continued respiratory distress. Monitoring of oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, and end-tidal CO2 is essential.

3. Renal Failure: The patient's history of ESRD and impaired renal function increase the risk of further deterioration in kidney

   73 yom HD-dependent, admitted with left acute on chronic SDH c/b
   seizure, transferred to MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and
   hypotension.
   # Sepsis: Continues with fevers most likely source is line infection.
   On day 9  vancomycin.  On and off pressors overnight with addition of
   midodren and florinef.    More likely due to abnormal autonomic
   dysfunction [**12-20**] to renal failure, but ddx includes infectious etiology
   given recent h/o sepsis.
   - Continue midodrine and florinef and reduce levophed as tolerated
   -keep MAP > 65
   -continue vancomycin given skin infection.
   - now febrile, may be bacteremic, surveillance cultures
   - d/c line in RIJ after placement of temporary femoral line
   - touch base with renal regarding posponing dialysis until new line
   placement
   # Respiratory Distress: Problem of inability to maintain secretions,
   based on failure of attempted trial of extubation.
   - On pressure support [**3-22**].  attempt extubation after d/w family re:
   reintubation and trach placement for long term ventilation
   - continue HD for volume overload
   - f/u sputum cx
   #Scrotal and buttock lesions
 most likely dependent skin ulcers
   - Herpes DFA - pending
   - continue wound care
   # Seizure: no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity; EEG is
   negative
   - Neuro recs: Bolused IV phenytoin 300mg and f/u dilantin level in AM
   - touch base re: anti-seizure regimen given -EEG
   # ESRD:
   - HD on monday
   - femoral temp line placement today
   - d/c of infected HD line
   # SDH: continue to hold anticoagulation, will follow neurology recs
   # Glaucoma /  Cataracts: continue home eye drops
   # DM: On SSI + lantus 40 daily; sugars well controlled 100-200
   # Access: axillary A-line, temp line for HD (infected); weaning
   pressors in attempt to pull HD line
   # Nutrition: tolerating TF
   # PPX: pneumoboots,  PPI; bowel reg
   # Code: full; confirmed with wife on admission via phone
   # Dispo: to remain in ICU while intubated
   -update family

Summary:
Summary of the progress note:
- The patient is a 73-year-old male who is HD-dependent and admitted with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizure.
- The patient has a history of renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and sepsis.
- The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.
- The patient has fevers, with a spike to 101.3°F, and hiccoughs.
- Blood and urine cultures were sent.
- The patient's blood pressure was in the 80s and required the use of pressors briefly.
- The patient has a temperature line placed and an infected HD line that needs to be pulled.
- The patient has scrotal and buttock lesions, most likely dependent skin ulcers, and is being treated with wound care.
- The patient had a seizure, but no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity, and an EEG is negative.
- The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is scheduled for hemodialysis on Monday.
- The patient has glaucoma and cataracts, for which he is receiving home eye drops.
- The patient's blood glucose levels are well controlled with insulin.
- The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line and a temporary femoral line.
- The patient is tolerating tube feeding (TF).

Potential medical complications:
1. Infection: The patient has fevers and an infected HD

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of subdural hematoma, persistent renal failure, and recurrent fever in the setting of sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently receiving treatment for several conditions.

1. Septic Shock: The patient continues to have low-grade fevers and requires low-dose pressor support. He is being treated with vancomycin for MRSA in his sputum and midodrine. Today, his right internal jugular (RIJ) line will be removed, and a femoral hemodialysis (HD) line will be placed.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's mental status has plateaued, and he is doing well on pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a tidal volume (Vt) of 532 mL. A reintubation plan needs to be established with the family before proceeding with extubation, which is likely to occur tomorrow. The possibility of a tracheostomy if extubation fails also needs to be discussed with the family.

3. Renal Failure: The patient's next hemodialysis session will be scheduled per renal consultation.

4. Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved from last week but has plateaued recently.

5. Seizure Disorder: The patient is being treated with neurontin and dilantin for his seizure disorder.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, the patient is critically ill and faces several potential medical complications. These include septic shock, respiratory failure, renal failure, subdural hematoma, and seizure disorder. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management in the ICU.

1. Septic shock: The patient has low-grade fevers and requires a low dose of norepinephrine, indicating ongoing septic shock. He is receiving vancomycin for suspected MRSA in his sputum and midodrine. The central venous line is being replaced from the right internal jugular vein to the femoral vein.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and his mental status has plateaued. There is a plan to establish a reintubation plan with the family before proceeding with extubation, likely tomorrow. The option of tracheostomy may be considered if extubation fails.

3. Renal Failure: The patient is scheduled for hemodialysis this afternoon.

4. Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved from last week but has plateaued.

5. Seizure Disorder: The patient is on Neurontin and Dilantin for seizure management.

Other issues are being managed by the ICU team. The patient's nutritional status, glycemic control, and lines (including arterial and venous access) are also being addressed

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted with a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing seizure. He has a history of renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and sepsis. He is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, hypoglycemia, and other medical complications. The patient has been on dialysis and has multiple lines and catheters inserted. His vital signs are stable, but he continues to have fevers, altered mental status, and difficulty maintaining secretions. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis and is on vancomycin. There is a concern for line infection as the most likely source of the infection. The patient remains on pressors despite the addition of midodrine and florinef.
2. Respiratory Distress: The patient is unable to maintain secretions, which led to the failure of attempted trial of extubation. He now requires direct tracheostomy placement. A spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and attempt at extubation will be done today.
3. Scrotal and Buttock Lesions: These are most likely dependent skin ulcers. The patient has tested negative for herpes simplex virus (DFA negative) and wound care will continue.
4. Seizure: Although there is no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity, the patient's EEG is negative. Neurology recommendations will be followed,

3. Scrotal and buttock lesions: These are most likely dependent skin ulcers. The patient has tested negative for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection using a direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test. Wound care will continue for these lesions.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, subdural hematoma, and renal failure. He has been experiencing ongoing fevers and intermittent pressor requirement, which indicates septic shock. The patient also has respiratory failure due to ongoing lack of improvement in mental status and ongoing secretions. He requires consultation for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG). Additionally, the patient has renal failure, for which he needs next hemodialysis session. The subdural hematoma and altered mental status are still present, although he is awake. The patient also has a seizure disorder, and medications like Neurontin and Dilantin have been initiated. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock: The patient's ongoing fevers and intermittent pressor requirement suggest ongoing infection and sepsis, which can lead to septic shock. Prompt treatment and control of the infection are crucial to prevent further complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's lack of improvement in mental status and ongoing secretions indicate ongoing respiratory failure. Tracheostomy and PEG may be necessary to improve his respiratory function.
3. Renal failure: The patient's persistent renal failure requires ongoing hemodialysis to manage fluid and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma may require surgical intervention to relieve pressure on the brain.
5. Seizure disorder

 most likely dependent skin ulcers

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male who is hospital-dependent and admitted with a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma causing seizure. He has been transferred to the MICU for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension. The patient continues to have fevers, and the source of infection is unclear but a CT scan suggests the possibility of osteomyelitis. His ESR is 80, which is lower than expected. He is on vancomycin for coverage of possible line infection and potential osteomyelitis, which should cover the most likely organisms (strep+staph). 

The patient also has respiratory distress due to the inability to maintain secretions, leading to failure of attempted trial of extubation. As a result, he will undergo tracheostomy placement today. He is NPO after midnight and will receive desmopressin (ddAVP) 30 minutes prior to the procedure due to low platelets. 

Furthermore, the patient has scrotal and buttock lesions, which are most likely dependent skin ulcers. A herpes DFA test was negative, and he will continue with wound care. 

Additionally, the patient experienced a seizure, but no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity was observed, and the EEG is negative. He will continue on fosphenytoin, with free phenytoin level checks every four days. 

The patient has end-stage renal disease

He was admitted due to a left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) causing seizures. The patient has been transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for concern of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.

The assessment and plan indicate that the patient continues to have fevers, with an unclear source but a possible infection in the bones (osteomyelitis) suggested by a CT scan. His ESR is low, which is not typical for this condition. The patient is on vancomycin, which is an antibiotic that covers possible line infections and certain bacteria that can cause osteomyelitis. The treatment plan includes continuing midodrine and florinef to maintain blood pressure, reducing levophed as tolerated, and keeping the mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65.

There is also a respiratory distress issue due to the inability to maintain secretions, leading to a failed trial of extubation. As a result, the patient will undergo tracheostomy placement today. Additionally, the patient has scrotal and buttock lesions, which are likely dependent skin ulcers. Wound care will be continued, and herpes DFA was negative.

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a history of subdural hematoma, encephalopathy, respiratory failure, and recurrent fever. He is currently in the ICU and has several medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has persistent renal failure and recurrent fever, which suggests the possibility of sepsis. The presence of fever spikes and ongoing infection raises concerns for septic shock.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires mechanical ventilation, indicating respiratory failure. The tracheostomy was performed today, and there is a consideration for a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube due to the patient's inability to eat.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has a history of renal failure and is undergoing hemodialysis. There were issues with the femoral HD line, and tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) was administered. Alternative access options may be necessary if the current catheter is inoperative.
4. Sub-Dural Hematoma/Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has plateaued, and he is more sleepy today. Management for seizure disorder, including neurontin and dilantin, is ongoing.
5. Seizure Disorder: The patient had seizures initially, and antiepileptic medications are being administered to manage this condition.

Overall, the patient's critical illness requires close monitoring and management of multiple medical complications, including se

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with left acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH), causing seizures. He is dependent on hemodialysis (HD) and was transferred to the MICU due to concerns of sepsis with hypoxia and hypotension.

The patient has been experiencing fevers, which have not been attributed to osteomyelitis based on MRI results. He has been on vancomycin for suspected line infection, despite negative cultures. The patient requires pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65. He also has respiratory distress, which improved after undergoing tracheostomy (trach). The patient continues to be agitated and tachypneic.

The patient has scrotal and buttock lesions that are likely dependent skin ulcers. A herpes DFA test was negative, and wound care is being continued. There is no evidence of ongoing seizure activity, and the EEG is negative. Phenytoin is being continued for seizure prophylaxis.

The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on hemodialysis with a femoral temporary line. Permanent access needs to be established. The patient's head injury is being managed by holding anticoagulation and following neurology recommendations.

The patient has glaucoma and cataracts, for which he is receiving home eye drops. If prolonged hospitalization continues, inpatient ophthalm

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male who is hospitalized in the ICU for acute on chronic subdural hematoma (SDH), resulting in seizures. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is dependent on hemodialysis (HD). He was admitted with sepsis, hypoxia, and hypotension, and is currently being treated with vancomycin for a suspected line infection, despite negative cultures. The patient also has eosinophilia, which raises the possibility of a drug reaction.

The patient's respiratory distress is attributed to a tracheostomy performed yesterday, which initially had some oozing but improved. The patient remains agitated and tachypneic, requiring increased sedation and assist-control ventilation (AC). Tracheostomy site monitoring, weaning of ventilation support, continuation of HD for volume overload, and follow-up sputum cultures are recommended.

The scrotal and buttock lesions are most likely dependent skin ulcers, with a negative herpes DFA. Wound care is advised.

The patient's seizure activity is not evident on EEG, so fosphenytoin has been continued, with regular free phenytoin level checks. It is also suggested to reassess the anti-seizure regimen due to concerns about dilantin causing clotting in HD.

Regarding ESRD, the patient should continue with femoral temporary HD access and explore more permanent access

   ESRD admitted with subdural hematomas after fall, now w/ poor mental
   status and persistent fevers.
   .
   # Fevers: Some improvement after d/c of fosphenytoin although one fever
   spike O/N to 101.  Has not required pressors for last 24 hrs although
   still on midodrine and florinef.  Have extensively searched for
   underlying source of fevers, including re-peated pancultures,  CT of
   chest, abdomen, pelvis.  The only findings have been  enlarged
   mediastinal lymph nodes: (1.5 x 2.1 cm prevascular lymph node and a
   precarinal lymph node measuring 2.2 x 0.7 cm).   Repeated sputum
   cultures show gram + cocci, however has already received long abx
   course for MRSA PNA and likely represents continued colonization.  Have
   D/c'd nonessential meds to eliminate possible sources of drug fever,
   including fosphenytoin yesterday.  Other tests not yet done for fever
   of unknown origin workup include: lower extremity US.
   -Can consider lower extremity US to search for DVT
   - Continue midodrine and florinef and reduce levophed as tolerated
   (hasn't required over last 24 hours): if no pressor requirement today,
   consider tapering off florinef and midodrine tomorrow
   - d/c all nonessential meds, vanc, dilantin
   - keep MAP > 65
   .
   #Mental Status change - Continues to be non-responsive to
   instructions.  Slight improvement in that he does make intermittent
   purposeful movements, including trying to remove trach.   Unclear
   underlying etiology: could be secondary to slow clearance of sedation
   or delirium of underlying infection versus effect of subdural
   hematomas.
   -Continue to hold sedation
   .
   # Respiratory Distress: Trach placed.   Had some oozing but improved.
   Attempt switch to pressure support today.
   - monitor trach site
   - continue HD for volume overload
   .
   #Scrotal and buttock lesions
 most likely dependent skin ulcers.
   Herpes DFA - negative
   - continue wound care
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), subdural hematomas, poor mental status, and persistent fevers. The patient has undergone extensive testing, including cultures, CT scans, and lower extremity ultrasound, to identify the underlying cause of the fevers. The only finding has been enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan, with repeated sputum cultures showing gram-positive cocci. However, this is believed to be colonization rather than an infection.

The patient's mental status has shown slight improvement, with intermittent purposeful movements, but remains non-responsive. The underlying etiology of the mental status change is unclear, with possible causes including sedation, infection, or the effect of subdural hematomas.

The patient's respiratory distress led to the placement of a tracheostomy tube. The tracheostomy site was initially oozing but improved, and pressure support is being attempted today. Close monitoring of the tracheostomy site is recommended.

The patient also has scrotal and buttock lesions, which are likely dependent skin ulcers. A herpes DFA test was negative, and wound care is being continued.

The patient experienced a seizure, but there is no gross evidence of ongoing seizure activity, and the EEG is negative. The neurology team's recommendations include tapering off dilantin and uptitrating keppra.

The patient is currently on hemodialysis (HD) with

The patient has been on mechanical ventilation since admission. His vital signs are stable, but he has been experiencing fevers, which have improved after discontinuing fosphenytoin. An extensive search for an underlying source of the fevers has been conducted, including CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, as well as repeated pancultures. Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes were found on the CT scans, but sputum cultures showed gram-positive cocci, which is likely colonization. Other tests, such as lower extremity ultrasound (US), are still pending for the fever of unknown origin workup.

The patient continues to be non-responsive to instructions with intermittent purposeful movements. The underlying etiology of the mental status change is unclear, potentially due to slow clearance of sedation, delirium secondary to infection, or the effect of subdural hematomas. Sedation will be continued, and neurology recommendations will be followed.

The patient's respiratory distress led to the placement of a tracheostomy, which improved his condition. Pressure support will be attempted today, and the tracheostomy site will be monitored. The patient has dependent skin ulcers on his scrotum and buttock

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), admitted with subdural hematomas after a fall. He presents with altered mental status and persistent fevers. The patient has been unresponsive to commands but shows some purposeful movements. The etiology of his altered mental status is unclear, possibly due to slow clearance of drugs/metabolites or residual effects from the subdural hematomas. Sedating drugs will be continued to be held.

The patient has persistent hypotension, and the etiology is uncertain. It could be autonomic dysfunction related to renal failure, adrenal insufficiency, or sepsis. A [Last Name (un)] stim test has been performed and is pending.

The patient requires respiratory support through a tracheostomy tube and is currently on pressure support ventilation (PSV). An attempt will be made to switch to pressure control mode for improved comfort.

Seizure activity has been monitored, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) has shown no evidence of ongoing seizure activity. Medication management for seizures will follow neurology recommendations.

The patient's ESRD is being managed with ongoing hemodialysis (HD). Access for HD is a concern, and more permanent access needs to be established, with consultation from the renal team.

Anticoagulation is being held due to the presence of subdural hematomas, and neurology recommendations will guide further management.

Overall

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an ESRD (End Stage Renal Disease) patient who was admitted with subdural hematomas after a fall. They have a history of poor mental status, persistent fevers, and various medical conditions including diabetes mellitus type II, seizure, impaired skin integrity, altered nutrition, respiratory failure, hypoglycemia, and renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has altered mental status and impaired skin integrity, which increases the risk of pressure ulcers or bedsores due to prolonged immobility.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to multiple factors such as sedation, underlying infection, or the effect of subdural hematomas. Close monitoring of neurological status and avoiding excessive sedation is necessary.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient is on assisted ventilation with a tracheostomy tube. There is a potential for respiratory distress due to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or complications related to tracheostomy.
4. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has persistent fevers despite negative workup for an underlying source. This could be attributed to drug fever or colonization with non-fermenter bacteria. Further investigations are required to identify the cause.
5. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has persistent elevated minute ventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis. Proper management of ventilation parameters and avoiding overbreathing

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an elderly male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus type II, seizure disorder, and impaired skin integrity. He was admitted with subdural hematomas after a fall and now presents with poor mental status, persistent fevers, and hypotension. The patient has been receiving various treatments including antibiotics, antiepileptic drugs, and dialysis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has altered mental status and impaired skin integrity, which increases the risk of developing pressure ulcers or bedsores due to prolonged immobility.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with an increased minute ventilation and overbreathing, indicating possible respiratory failure. There is also a plan to switch from assist-control (AC) mode to pressure support mode for improved comfort.
3. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's blood gases show a high CO2 level, suggesting metabolic alkalosis due to overbreathing.
4. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fevers and leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, possibly leading to sepsis.
5. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's persistent hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation raises the suspicion of adrenal insufficiency, especially considering the renal failure.
6. Renal Failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease and requires ongoing dialysis to manage his kidney failure.

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus type II, seizure disorder, and impaired skin integrity. He was admitted with subdural hematomas after a fall and now presents with poor mental status, persistent fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient has been on multiple medications including antibiotics, antiepileptics, and sedatives. He has undergone various tests and procedures such as ultrasound, cultures, and imaging studies. The patient's condition remains unstable, and several potential medical complications have been identified.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has non-healing lesions on his scrotum and buttocks, which are most likely dependent skin ulcers. Wound care is ongoing.
2. Fever of unknown origin (FUO): The patient has persistent fevers despite extensive workup, including negative cultures. Possible causes include drug fever or colonization with non-fermenter bacteria.
3. Altered mental status: The patient is non-responsive to instructions with intermittent purposeful movements. The underlying etiology is unclear, but could be due to sedation, infection, or subdural hematomas.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient requires assisted ventilation with intermittent overbreathing. There is a need to switch to pressure support and monitor the tracheostomy site.
5. Renal failure: The patient has ESRD requiring hemodialysis (HD

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) admitted to the ICU for subdural hematomas after a fall. The patient presents with poor mental status and persistent fevers. The patient has been evaluated for fever of unknown origin (FUO), and no underlying source has been identified. The patient has received a long course of antibiotics for MRSA pneumonia, but sputum cultures show gram-positive cocci, indicating colonization rather than infection. The patient continues to have persistent hypotension, which may be due to poor autonomic function, renal failure, sepsis, or adrenal insufficiency. The patient's metabolic alkalosis is worsening, and respiratory distress persists. The patient's mental status change is non-responsive to instructions, but there has been slight improvement. The patient has dependent skin ulcers, likely due to pressure sores, and herpes DFA is negative. There is no evidence of ongoing seizure activity, and EEG is negative. The patient's ESRD requires ongoing hemodialysis (HD) with a femoral temporary line, and more permanent access needs to be established. The patient has several other medical issues, including glaucoma/cataracts, diabetes mellitus (DM), access problems, and prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Persistent Hypotension

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with subdural hematomas following a fall. The patient is currently experiencing poor mental status and persistent fevers. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 128/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's current weight is 84.5 kg, and the admission weight was 94.2 kg.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.6 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels ranging from 5.3 to 7.6 mg/dL, and elevated glucose levels up to 272 mg/dL. Other lab results indicate abnormalities in potassium, sodium, chloride, bicarbonate, and liver enzymes.

Imaging studies reveal the presence of subdural hematomas. The sputum gram stain shows gram-negative rods and gram-positive cocci, but blood cultures are negative. The patient has received a long course of antibiotics for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and likely represents continued colonization.
